awd_titl_txt: Design and Fabrication of a Device for Non-Invasive Transdermal Opioid Biomarker Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design and develop innovative medical products to address the opioid crisis in the U.S. Although blood is the body fluid which provides the most accurate quantitative data on biomolecular concentration when compared with other traditional sample matrices, blood-draws are extremely invasive, uncomfortable and, in the context of persons either denying or dealing with opioid addiction, are met with resistance and trepidation. An expanding pathway for biomolecular detection is through interstitial fluid
(ISF), which surrounds cells in all living tissue and organs, and contains constituents of blood.  By passively harvesting this fluid from just beneath the skin surface in a non-invasive, non-inflammatory manner, blood-borne biomarkers for illicit opioid use can be detected in the ISF using traditional clinical tools. 

An important advantage of harvesting ISF using a non-invasive dermal patch, or Band-Aid-like devices, is that the fluid is pre-filtered by the capillary system so that large biomolecules do not exist in the sample.  Specifically, the device will sample ISF via noninvasive micro-pore generation using highly-controlled micro-heater ablation of the uppermost (dead) skin layer. The microliter quantity of ISF exuded from the skin can be transported via microfluidics to a reservoir for subsequent external pipetting. Using the laboratory facilities at the FDA-CDRH the detection of standard biomarkers of opioid abuse will be undertaken using the sampled ISF biomarker (meconin, and other standard opioid abuse biomarkers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Current medical practice for disease diagnostics requires the monitoring of specific biomarkers in body fluids, typically blood and/or urine. The consistency, reliability, and therefore effectiveness of such techniques often hinges on its collection.  Apprehension and anxiety can make this challenging since blood sampling from finger pricks and hypodermic blood draws can be quite painful, with the latter often requiring medical supervision and time-consuming post-processing.  When urine samples are required, these can be easily tainted/contaminated or in certain situations, tampered/corrupted, and therefore intrusive monitoring is necessary to oversee collection for proper testing.  As an alternative body fluid, researchers have turned to health monitoring using interstitial fluid (ISF), the extracellular fluid that bathes every living cell/tissue in the body. ISF acts as a reservoir and transportation system that provides nutrients from the circulatory system to tissues while removing cellular metabolic waste back into the blood.  The tiny blood vessels, called capillaries, have walls made of tightly-bound cells, which include small separations, or nano-crevices, that allow bidirectional passage of small molecules into and out of these capillaries. As a result of this process, called capillary exchange, ISF?s composition largely mirrors that of blood, but without larger constituents like red and white blood cells and platelets, that cannot pass through the nano-crevices.  Microneedles are the most popular technology for sampling ISF.  Typically ranging from 0.2?2 mm in length, these devices puncture the skin and are less invasive than typical hypodermic needles, including those used with continuous glucose monitors. Microneedle-based devices can extract ISF transdermally, i.e. through the skin, and multiple extraction mechanisms have been realized, including microneedles that are hollow or porous, suction-based, and diffusion of ISF into gel-based microneedles.  Although microneedles are often referred to as ?non-invasive?, they nonetheless penetrate the skin and are not pain-free. The dermis contains nerve endings, and the pain associated with insertion of microneedle-based devices scales with the length and the number of needles in an array. Furthermore, they are susceptible to fracture and, as the physics of lying on a bed of nails illustrates, microneedle arrays can require significant insertion force.

Needle-free approaches to collect ISF often work by thermally compromising the stratum corneum (SC), the outermost barrier layer of flattened, dehydrated skin cells. The SC can be permeated using pulsed lasers or steam, but these approaches are complicated to integrate in a simple user-friendly platform for point-of-care applications.  Iontophoretic devices using electric fields have been used in the past to determine glucose concentration in ISF, but are no longer available because of issues including skin irritation, burns, and inadvertent shutdown during critical periods of hypoglycemia.

In this research, a simple, wearable patch device has been developed for painless, non-invasive, and non-intrusive sampling of ISF. The patch features a microscopic array of resistive micro-heating elements (visualize microscopic heating coils from an electric cooktop stove) that each thermally ablate a minuscule micro-pore in the SC, through which ISF can passively emerge due to hydrostatic pressure provided by the heart, and be collected within the device. The patch micro-heaters each generate safe temperature gradients by heating the skin surface just above 130 ?C for an extremely short time (thousandths of a second). Using preliminary modeling, in-vitro/ex-vivo experimental verification, and a pilot clinical trial, the micro-heaters reliably generate micro-pores in the SC with no pain, sensation, or skin damage.  Additionally, sufficient amounts of ISF can be collected for off-line analyses without necessitating any sample post-processing.

ISF volume collected by the thermal skin patch was compared with reported volumes collected using microneedle-based techniques.  The patch is able to collect the same or even more ISF volume compared with microneedle-based approaches, and in a significantly faster time.  This technology has already been used successfully to monitor glucose and lactate with clinically relevant accuracy, and for the this research, the dermal patch is being used for illicit opioid use. Monitoring of opioid abuse is typically conducted with intrusive urine testing, and would benefit from a simpler sampling technique. Here, the harvested ISF is collected and utilized in both electrochemical and mass spectrometric analyses to detect specific metabolites of ?street? opioids.  Successful sampling of ISF in sufficient volumes for off-line analysis, and the detection of target opioid biomarkers illustrates this platform technology?s potential in personalized medicine using non-invasive biomolecular monitoring in an alternative human body fluid.

 


Last Modified: 03/24/2023
Modified by: Makarand Paranjape

Image
  • The fully flexible transdermal patch fabricated using Kapton bonded with hydrophilic PDMS containing a network of microfluidic channels.
    M. Paranjape, D. O'Brien
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Makarand Paranjape
    Flexible Transdermal Patch for Biomarker Detection
